# Finite, Infinite and Denumerable Sets and Cardinal Numbers

We say that sets $A$ and $B$ are equinumerous if and only if there is a one-one correspondence between $A$ and $B$, $F: A \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} B$. We shall write $A \approx B$ to mean that $A$ and $B$ are equinumerous.

::: {#thm-equinumerous-equivalence-relation}

If $\mathscr{F}$ is an arbitrary collection of sets where $A \in \mathscr{F}$, $B \in \mathscr{F}$ and $C \in \mathscr{F}$ then $\approx$ is an equivalence relation on $\mathscr{F}$:

a. $A \approx A$
b. $A \approx B \Longrightarrow B \approx A$
c. $(A \approx B \land B \approx C) \Longrightarrow A \approx C$

:::

::: {.proof}

a. Let $I_A: A \longrightarrow A$ be the identity function on $A$ where $I_A(x) = x$ for all $x \in A$. Because $I_A: A \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} A$ then $A \approx A$.

b. If $A \approx B$ then there is a $F$ such that $F: A \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} B$. By @thm-inverse-function-as-a-function $F^{-1}: B \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} A$ so $B \approx A$.

c. If $A \approx B$ and $B \approx C$ there exist $F$ and $G$ such that $F: A \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} B$ and $G: B \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} C$. By @cor-composition-functions-one-one-correspondence $G \circ F: A \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} C$, so $A \approx C$. 

:::

::: {#exr-equinumerous-relation}

1. If $A \approx \emptyset$ prove that $A = \emptyset$

2. Prove that $A \approx A \times {y}$ (Hint: Let $\theta(a) = (a,y)$ for all $a \in A$)

:::

::: {#sol-equinumerous-relation}

1. If $A \approx \emptyset$ then $F: A \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} \emptyset$. Because $\mathscr{D}(F) = A$ we have that $\mathscr{D}(F) = \{ x \mid \exists y (F(x) = y)\}$ where $y \in \mathscr{R}(F)$. However $\mathscr{R}(F) \subseteq \emptyset$ so $\mathscr{R}(F) = \emptyset$. Therefore there is no $y$ such that $F(x) = y$, which means that $A$ has no elements. So, $A = \emptyset$.

2. Let $\theta(a) = (a,y)$ for all $a \in A$. First assume that $\theta(a) = \theta(b)$ then $(a, y) = (b, y)$. By @exr-axiom-of-pairing 1 $a = b$ so $\theta(a)$ is one-one. Now let any $(a,y) \in A \times \{ y \}$ then $a \in A$ and $\theta(a) = (a,y)$ so $\theta(a)$ is onto. Therefore $\theta(a): A \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} A \times \{ y \}$, so $A \approx A \times \{ y \}$.   

:::

Two sets which are equinumerous are said to have the same cardinal number. We assume that each set $A$ has an associate cardinal number $\mathscr{K}(A)$. Hence, $\mathscr{K}(A) = \mathscr{K}(B) \iff A \approx B$.

::: {#def-less-equal-than-and-less-than-relation-sets}

If $\mathscr{F}$ is an arbitrary collection of sets where $A \in \mathscr{F}$ and $B \in \mathscr{F}$ the relations $\leq$ and $<$ on $\mathscr{F}$ are defined as:  

a. $A \leq B \iff \exists F (F: A \xrightarrow[]{1-1} B)$

b. $A < B \iff A \leq B \land A \not \approx B$

**Note**: $A \not \approx B$ means $\neg(A \approx B)$. Therefore $A \leq B \land A \not \approx B$ means that $\exists F (F: A \xrightarrow[]{1-1} B \land \neg(F: A \xrightarrow[onto]{} B))$ 

:::

::: {#thm-less-equal-than-and-less-than-relation-sets}

If $\mathscr{F}$ is an arbitrary collection of sets where $A \in \mathscr{F}$, $B \in \mathscr{F}$ and $C \in \mathscr{F}$ then:

a. $A \leq A$

b. $A \leq B \land B \leq C \Longrightarrow A \leq C$

c. $A \not < A$

d. $B \subseteq A \Longrightarrow B \leq A$

e. $A \leq B \iff (A < B \lor A \approx B)$

f. $B \leq A \iff \exists W (W \subseteq A \land B \approx W)$

g. $(A \leq B \land B \approx C) \Longrightarrow A \leq C$

h. $(A \approx B \land B \leq C) \Longrightarrow A \leq C$

:::

::: {.proof}

a. Because $A \approx A$ then there is some $F: A \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} A$. Therefore $F$ is one-one which means that $A \leq A$.

b. If $A \leq B$ and $B \leq C$ then there exist $F$ and $G$ such that $F: A \xrightarrow[]{1-1} B$ and $G: B \xrightarrow[]{1-1} C$. By @thm-composition-functions-one-one $G \circ F: A \xrightarrow[]{1-1} C$ so $A \leq C$.

c. $A \not < A$ means that $\neg (A < A)$. By @def-less-equal-than-and-less-than-relation-sets b it means that $\neg (A \leq A) \lor \neg(A \not \approx A)$. Therefore we have that $\neg (A \leq A) \lor (A \approx A)$. We know by @thm-less-equal-than-and-less-than-relation-sets that $\neg (A \leq A)$ is false and by @thm-equinumerous-equivalence-relation that $A \approx A$ is true. Therefore $\neg (A \leq A) \lor (A \approx A)$ is true, which means that $A \not < A$ is true.   

d.  By @thm-equinumerous-equivalence-relation $I_A: A \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} A$. Therefore ${I_A \mid}_{B}: B \xrightarrow[]{1-1} A$ where ${I_A \mid}_{B}$ is the restriction of $I_A$ to the domain $B$ [See @stoll_sets_1974, p. 40]. So $B \leq A$.

e.  $\begin{aligned}
     A \leq B & \iff \exists F (F: A \xrightarrow[]{1-1} B) \\
     & \iff \exists F (F: A \xrightarrow[]{1-1} B) \land (\exists F (F: A \xrightarrow[onto]{} B) \lor \neg \exists F (F: A \xrightarrow[onto]{} B)) \\
     & \iff (\exists F (F: A \xrightarrow[]{1-1} B) \land \exists F (F: A \xrightarrow[onto]{} B)) \lor (\exists F (F: A \xrightarrow[]{1-1} B) \land \neg \exists F (F: A \xrightarrow[onto]{} B)) \\
     & \iff A \approx B \lor A < B
     \end{aligned}$

f. $\begin{aligned}
     B \leq A & \iff \exists F (F: B \xrightarrow[]{1-1} A) \\
     & \iff \exists F (F: B \xrightarrow[]{1-1} A \land W = \mathscr{R}(F) \subseteq A) \\
     & \iff \exists F (F: B \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} W \land W \subseteq A) \\ 
     & \iff \exists W (B \approx W \land W \subseteq A)
     \end{aligned}$. 

g. If $A \leq B$ and $B \approx C$ there exist $F$ and $G$ such that $F: A \xrightarrow[]{1-1} B$ and $G: B \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} C$. By @thm-composition-functions-one-one $G \circ F: A \xrightarrow[]{1-1} C$, so $A \leq C$. 

h. If $A \approx B$ and $B \leq C$ there exist $F$ and $G$ such that $F: A \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} B$ and $G: B \xrightarrow[]{1-1} C$. By @thm-composition-functions-one-one $G \circ F: A \xrightarrow[]{1-1} C$, so $A \leq C$. 

:::

We can define an order relation $<_K$ on cardinal numbers. Let $\mathfrak{m}$ and $\mathfrak{n}$ be cardinal numbers. Take any sets $A$ and $B$ having cardinal numbers $\mathfrak{m}$ and $\mathfrak{n}$ respectively. By @thm-less-equal-than-and-less-than-relation-sets g and h it does not make any difference in these definitions which sets $A$ and $B$ we choose having cardinal numbers $\mathfrak{m}$ and $\mathfrak{n}$, respectively.  

One can obtain theorems about cardinal numbers analogous to those proved above. For example, the analogue of @thm-less-equal-than-and-less-than-relation-sets b is $(\mathfrak{m} <_K \mathfrak{n} \land \mathfrak{n} <_K \mathfrak{p}) \Longrightarrow \mathfrak{m} <_K \mathfrak{p}$, for any cardinal numbers $\mathfrak{m}$, $\mathfrak{n}$ and $\mathfrak{p}$.

::: {#thm-cantor-theorem}

## Cantor theorem

If $A$ is a set then:

$$A < \mathscr{P}(A)$$
:::

::: {.proof}

If $A < \mathscr{P}(A)$ by @def-less-equal-than-and-less-than-relation-sets b we need to prove that $A \leq \mathscr{P}(A) \land A \not \approx \mathscr{P}(A)$.

First, define $F$ such that $F(a) = \{ a \}$ for all $a \in A$ then $F: A \xrightarrow[]{1-1} \mathscr{P}(A)$ becuase if $F(a) = F(b)$ then $\{ a \} = \{ b \}$ so $a = b$. Therefore, $A \leq \mathscr{P}(A)$.

Second, using @nte-proof-by-reductio-ad-absurdum assume $A \approx \mathscr{P}(A)$ so there is some $G$ such that $G: A \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} \mathscr{P}(A)$. Let $B = \{ b \in A \mid b \not \in G(b) \}$. Because $B \subseteq A$ then $B \in \mathscr{P}(A)$ therefore because $G$ is onto it exists some $a \in A$ such that $G(a) = B$. There are 2 possibilities $a \in B$ or $a \not \in B$:

i.  If $a \in B$ then $a \not \in G(a)$. But $G(a) = B$ so we have also that $a \in G(a)$.

ii. If $a \not \in B$ then because $G(a) = B$ we have that $a \not \in G(a)$. However this means that $a \in B$.

In any case there is a contradiction so it is not the case that $A \approx \mathscr{P}(A)$. Therefore it must be the case that $A \not \approx \mathscr{P}(A)$.

Because $A \leq \mathscr{P}(A)$ and $A \not \approx \mathscr{P}(A)$ we have that $A < \mathscr{P}(A)$.

:::

::: {#thm-schroder-bernstein-theorem}

## Schröder-Bernstein theorem

If $A$ and $B$ are sets then:

$$(A \leq B \land B \leq A) \Longrightarrow A \approx B$$

:::

::: {.proof}

## Based on [@mendelson_introduction_2015, pp. 295-296]

Assume $A \cap B = \emptyset$. If it is not the case we can define $A_1 = A \times \{ 0 \}$ and $B_1 = B \times \{ 1 \}$ where by @exr-equinumerous-relation 2 $A \approx A_1$ and $B \approx B_1$ and we can use @thm-less-equal-than-and-less-than-relation-sets g, h to still prove @thm-schroder-bernstein-theorem.  

Let us assume $F: A \xrightarrow[]{1-1} B$ and $G: B \xrightarrow[]{1-1} A$. By a B-thread (See @fig-b-thread) we mean a function $f$ from the set $\mathbb{P}$ of positive integers into $A \cup B$, $f: \mathbb{P} \longrightarrow A \cup B$, such that:

-  $y_1 = f(1) \in B - \mathscr{R}(F)$
-  $f(n) \in B \Longrightarrow f(n+1) = G(f(n))$
-  $f(n) \in A \Longrightarrow f(n+1) = F(f(n))$

Therefore $f(1) = y_1 \in B - \mathscr{R}(F)$, $f(2) = G(f(1)) \in A$, $f(3) = F(f(2)) \in B$, $f(4) = F(f(3)) \in A, \ldots$, $f(2n) = G(f(2n - 1)) \in A$, $f(2n+1) = F(f(2n)) \in B, \ldots$. 

Thus, a B-thread is an infinite sequence of points starting with a point $y_1$, which is not in the range of $F$, and then using the functions $G$ and $F$ alternately.

Let $W = \{ w \in A \mid w \in \mathscr{R}(f) \}$. Then the desired one-one correspondence $H$ between $A$ and $B$ is given by:

$$H(x) = \begin{cases}
          {G^{-1} \mid}_{W}(x) & \text{if } x \in W \\
          {F \mid}_{A - W}(x) & \text{if } x \in W - A
            \end{cases}$$

Where ${G^{-1} \mid}_{W}$ is the restriction of $G^{-1}$, that is $G^{-1}: \mathscr{R}(G) \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} B$, to the domain $W$ and ${F \mid}_{W - A}$ is the restriction of $F$ to the domain $A - W$ [See @stoll_sets_1974, p. 40].

We have that:

$$\begin{split}
   \mathscr{D}(H) & = \{ x \mid \exists y (H(x) = y) \} \\
   & = \{ x \mid \exists y ({G^{-1} \mid}_{W}(x) = y \lor {F \mid}_{A - W}(x) = y) \} \\
   & = \{ x \mid \exists y ({G^{-1} \mid}_{W}(x) = y) \lor \exists y ({F \mid}_{A - W}(x) = y) \} \\
   & = \{ x \mid \exists y ({G^{-1} \mid}_{W}(x) = y) \} \cup \{ x \mid \exists y (F(x) = y) \} \\
   & = \mathscr{D}({G^{-1} \mid}_{W}) \cup \mathscr{D}({F \mid}_{A - W}) \\
   & = W \cup W - A \\
   & = A
   \end{split}$$

Also because ${G^{-1} \mid}_{W}: W \xrightarrow[]{1-1} B$ where $\mathscr{R}({G^{-1} \mid}_{W}) \subseteq B$ and ${F \mid}_{A - W}: A - W \xrightarrow[]{1-1} B$ where $\mathscr{R}({F \mid}_{A - w}) \subseteq B$, we have also that:

$$\begin{split}
   \mathscr{R}(H) & = \{ y \mid \exists x (H(x) = y) \} \\
   & = \{ y \mid \exists x ({G^{-1} \mid}_{W}(x) = y \lor {F \mid}_{A - W}(x) = y) \} \\
   & = \{ y \mid \exists x ({G^{-1} \mid}_{W}(x) = y) \lor \exists x ({F \mid}_{A - W}(x) = y) \} \\
   & = \{ y \mid \exists x ({G^{-1} \mid}_{W}(x) = y) \} \cup \{ y \mid \exists x (F(x) = y) \} \\
   & = \mathscr{R}({G^{-1} \mid}_{W}) \cup \mathscr{R}({F \mid}_{A - W}) \\
   & \Longrightarrow \mathscr{R}(H) \subseteq B
   \end{split}$$

Furthermore, if $xHy$ and $xHz$ then $x{G^{-1} \mid}_{W}y$ and $x{G^{-1} \mid}_{W}z$ or $x{F \mid}_{A - W}y$ and $x{F \mid}_{A - W}z$ but not both. Because ${G^{-1} \mid}_{W}$ and ${F \mid}_{A - W}$ are functions we have that $y = z$. So $H$ is also a function. Therefore $H: A \longrightarrow B$ where now we need to prove that is a one-one correspondence.

-  First we prove that $H$ is onto. Let $b \in B$ then $G(b) \in W$ or $G(b) \in A - W$.

    -  If $G(b) \in W$ then $H(G(b)) = {G^{-1} \mid}_{W}(G(b)) = b$ taking into account that $G: B \xrightarrow[]{1-1} A$, $G^{-1}: \mathscr{R}(G) \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} B$, ${G^{-1} \mid}_{W}: W \xrightarrow[]{1-1} B$ and $W \subseteq \mathscr{R}(G) \subseteq A$.
    
    -  If $G(b) \in A - W$ then $G(b) \in A$ and $G(b) \not \in W$. Also $H(G(b)) = F(G(b))$ and it must be the case that $F(G(b)) = b$. Why? If this is not the case then $b \in B - \mathscr{R}(F)$ so there will be a B-thread such that $f(1) = b$ where $G(b) = f(2) \in A$. Therefore $G(b) = f(2) \in W$ but we have assume that $G(b) \not \in W$. 

-  Second we prove that $H$ is one-one. Using @nte-proof-by-reductio-ad-absurdum assume that $H(x) = H(y)$ and $x \neq y$

    -  $x$ and $y$ can not be both in $W$ because ${G^{-1} \mid}_{W}$ is one-one
    -  $x$ and $y$ can not be both in $A - W$ because ${F \mid}_{A - W}$ is one-one
    -  Let $x \in W$ and $y \in A - W$. Then $x = {G^{-1} \mid}_{W}(x) = {F \mid}_{A - W}(y)$, so $x = G({G^{-1} \mid}_{W}(x)) = G({F \mid}_{A - W}(y))$ because ${G^{-1} \mid}_{W} : W \xrightarrow[]{1-1} B$ and $G: B \xrightarrow[]{1-1} A$. Therefore, $G({F \mid}_{A - W}(y)) = x$ and $G({F \mid}_{A - W}(y)) \in W$ but this means that $y$ is also in the same B-thread as $x$. So, $y \in W$ but we have also that $y \in A - W$ which means that $y \not \in W$. Taking into account that we arrive to a contradiction it must be the case that $H$ is one-one.[^appendix_d-1]   
        
:::

[^appendix_d-1]: For another proof of @thm-schroder-bernstein-theorem check out [@halevi_fraenkel_abstract_1961, pp. 73-77]

![B-thread](images/fig-b-thread.png){#fig-b-thread fig-align="center" width=40%}

::: {.proof}

## Based on [@peloquin_cantor-schroeder-bernstein_2016] and [@enderton_elements_2009, pp. 147-148]

Let $G: B \longrightarrow A$ and $C \subseteq B$ then $G[C] = \mathscr{R}({G \mid}_{C}) = \{ G(c) \mid c \in C \}$ where ${G \mid}_{C}$ is the restriction of $G$ to the domain $C$ [See @stoll_sets_1974, p. 40].

Let $F: A \xrightarrow[]{1-1} B$ and $G: B \xrightarrow[]{1-1} A$. Also define $A_1 = A - G[B]$, $A_{n+1} = (G \circ F)[A_n]$ and $A_{\infty} = \bigcup_{n = 1}^{\infty} A_n$ (See @fig-schroder-bernstein-theorem-mirrors).

Now define $H: A \longrightarrow B$ to be:

$$H(x) = \begin{cases}
          F(x) &  \text{if } x \in A_{\infty} \\
          G^{-1}(x) & \text{if } x \in A - A_{\infty}
            \end{cases}$$

Now we need to prove that $H$ is a one-one correspondence.

- Lets prove that $H$ is one-one, that is if $H(x) = H(y)$ then $x = y$

    -  If $x$ and $y$ are in $A_{\infty}$ because $F$ is one-one then $H(x) = F(x)$ and $H(y) = F(y)$ so $F(x) = F(y)$ implies that $x = y$
    
    -  If $x$ and $y$ are in $A - A_{\infty}$ by @thm-inverse-function-as-a-function $G^{-1}: \mathscr{R}(G) \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} B$. So $G^{-1}$ is one-one, which means that $H(x) = G^{-1}(x)$ and $H(y) = G^{-1}(y)$ so $G^{-1}(x) = G^{-1}(y)$ implies that $x = y$.
    
    -  If $x \in A_{\infty}$, $y \in A - A_{\infty}$ and $H(x) = H(y)$ then $F(x) = G^{-1}(y)$. Therefore $G(F(x)) = G(G^{-1}(y)) = y$, so $G(F(x)) = y$. Because $x \in A_{\infty}$ then $x$ belongs to some $A_n$ so $G(F(x)) \in A_{n + 1}$. Therefore $y \in A_{n + 1}$ and $y \in A_{\infty}$. However this is a contradiction because we assume that $y \in A - A_{\infty}$. This means that we need to discard this case.
    
  Therefore $H$ is one-one.

- Lets prove that $H$ is onto, that is for any $b \in B$ it exists $a \in A$ such that $H(a) = b$. Because $G: B \xrightarrow[]{1-1} A$ then $G(b) \in A - A_{\infty}$ or $G(b) \in A_{\infty}$.  

    -  If $G(b) \in A_{\infty}$ then $H(G(b)) = G^{-1}(G(b)) = b$. So $H(G(b)) = b$ where $G(b) \in A$
    
    -  If $G(b) \in A_{\infty}$ then $G(b)$ belongs to some $A_n$. It can not be $A_1 = A - G[B]$ because $G(b) \in G[B]$. So $G(b)$ must belong to some $A_{n+1} = (G \circ F)[A_n]$. Therefore we have that $G(b) = G(F(a))$ for some $a \in A_n$, so $a \in A_{\infty}$. Then we have that $b = G^{-1}(G(b)) = G^{-1}(G(F(a))) = F(a) = H(a)$ because $a \in A_{\infty}$. So $H(a) = b$ where $a \in A$.
    
  Therefore $H$ is onto.
:::

![Schröder-Bernstein theorem proof using mirrors](images/fig-schroder-bernstein-theorem-mirrors.png){#fig-schroder-bernstein-theorem-mirrors fig-align="center" width=90%}

::: {#exm-schroder-bernstein-theorem}

Let $F: \mathbb{P} \xrightarrow[]{1-1} \mathbb{P}$ where $F(n) = n + 1$ and $G: \mathbb{P} \xrightarrow[]{1-1} \mathbb{P}$ where $G(n) = n + 2$. Then $g[\mathbb{P}] = \{ 3, 4, 5, \ldots \}$, so:

- $A_1 = \mathbb{P} - g[\mathbb{P}] = \{ 1, 2 \}$

Also we have that $G(F(1)) = G(2) = 4$, $G(F(2)) = G(3) = 5$, so:

- $A_2 = (G \circ F)[A_1] = \{ 4, 5 \}$

Furthermore $G(F(4)) = G(2) = 7$, $G(F(5)) = G(3) = 8$, so:

- $A_3 = (G \circ F)[A_2] = \{ 7, 8 \}$

In general, we have that:

- $A_n = (G \circ F)[A_{n - 1}] = \{ 3n - 2, 3n - 1 \}$

Therefore, we have that:

- $A_{\infty} = \bigcup_{n = 1}^{\infty} A_n = \bigcup_{n = 1}^{\infty} \{ 3n - 2, 3n - 1 \} = \{ 1, 2, 4, 5, 7, 8, \ldots, 3n - 2, 3n - 1, \ldots \}$

- $A - A_{\infty} = \{ 3, 6, 9, \ldots, 3n, \ldots \}$

Finally we have that $H$ is defined as:

$$H(n) = \begin{cases}
          n + 1 &  \text{if } n = 3m - 2 \text{ or } n = 3m - 1 \text{ for some } m \in \mathbb{P} \\
          n - 2 & \text{if } n = 3m \text{ for some } m \in \mathbb{P}
            \end{cases}$$

:::

::: {#cor-schroder-bernstein-theorem}

a. $A \leq B \Longrightarrow B \not < A$

b. $(A \leq B \land B < C) \Longrightarrow A < C$

c. $(A < B \land B \leq C) \Longrightarrow A < C$

d. $(A < B \land B < C) \Longrightarrow A < C$

:::

::: {.proof}

a. Using @nte-proof-by-reductio-ad-absurdum assume that $A \leq B \land \neg(B \not < A)$ then $A \leq B \land B < A)$. By @def-less-equal-than-and-less-than-relation-sets b $A \leq B \land (B \leq A \land B \not \approx A))$ and by @thm-schroder-bernstein-theorem $B \approx A \land B \not \approx A$. Because there is a contradiction we have that $A \leq B \Longrightarrow B \not < A$ is true.

b. If $A \leq B$ and $B < C$ then by @def-less-equal-than-and-less-than-relation-sets b $B \leq C$ and $B \not \approx C$. Because $A \leq B$ and $B \leq C$ by @thm-less-equal-than-and-less-than-relation-sets $A \leq C$. 

   Now using @nte-proof-by-reductio-ad-absurdum assume that $A \approx C$ then $C \leq A$. Because $A \leq B$ then again by @thm-less-equal-than-and-less-than-relation-sets $C \leq B$. Because we have also that $B \leq C$ by @thm-schroder-bernstein-theorem $B \approx C$ but $B \not \approx C$. Because there is a contradiction it must be that $A \not \approx C$.
   
   We have that $A \leq C$ and $A \not \approx C$ so by @def-less-equal-than-and-less-than-relation-sets b $A < C$.
   
c. Because $A < B$ then $A \leq B$. Also because $B \leq C$ then $A \leq C$. 

   Let use @nte-proof-by-reductio-ad-absurdum. Assume $A \approx C$ then $C \approx A$ and because $B \leq C$ by @thm-less-equal-than-and-less-than-relation-sets g $B \leq A$. But by @cor-schroder-bernstein-theorem $A \not < B$. However, $A < B$, so there is a contradiction and it must be the case that $A \not \approx C$.
   
   Because $A \leq C$ and $A \not \approx C$ then $A < C$.
   
d. If $A < B$ and $B < C$ then $A \leq B$ and $B \leq C$. Therefore $A \leq C$.

   Let use @nte-proof-by-reductio-ad-absurdum. Assume $A \approx C$ then $C \approx A$ so $C \leq A$. Because $A \leq B$ then $C \leq B$, so by @cor-schroder-bernstein-theorem $B \not < C$. But $B < C$, so there is a contradiction and it must be the case that $A \not \approx C$.
   
   Because $A \leq C$ and $A \not \approx C$ then $A < C$. 

:::

All the results in @cor-schroder-bernstein-theorem and others formulated in terms of $\approx$, $\leq$ and $<$ can be reformulated in terms of cardinal numbers. For example @cor-schroder-bernstein-theorem a becomes $\mathfrak{m} \leq_K \mathfrak{n} \Longrightarrow \mathfrak{n} \not <_K \mathfrak{m}$ for any cardinal numbers $\mathfrak{m}$ and $\mathfrak{n}$.

::: {#exr-schroder-bernstein-theorem}

1. Prove that there is no universal set $U$ of all sets. (Hint: $\mathscr{P}(U) \leq U$ since $\mathscr{P}(U) \subseteq U$. Use @cor-schroder-bernstein-theorem a and @thm-cantor-theorem) 

:::

::: {#sol-schroder-bernstein-theorem}

1. Let use @nte-proof-by-reductio-ad-absurdum. If there is a universal set $U$ then $\mathscr{P}(U) \subseteq U$. By @thm-less-equal-than-and-less-than-relation-sets d $\mathscr{P}(U) \leq U$ but by @cor-schroder-bernstein-theorem a $U \not < \mathscr{P}(U)$. However, by @thm-cantor-theorem $U < \mathscr{P}(U)$, so there is a contradiction and it must be the case that there is no universal set $U$.

:::

Another apparently simple fact about sets is that, for any sets $A$ and $B$ either $A \leq B$ or $B \leq A$. This result is know as the Trichotomy Law[^appendix_d-2] and turns out to be equivalent to the Axiom of Choice.

[^appendix_d-2]: In the case of cardinal numbers if $\mathfrak{m}$ and $\mathfrak{n}$ are cardinal numbers then $\mathfrak{m} {\leq}_K \mathfrak{n}$ or $\mathfrak{m} {\geq}_K \mathfrak{n}$. 

The Axiom of Choice states that if $A$ is any set of non empty sets, then there is a function $F$ with domain $A$, $\mathscr{D}(F) = A$ such that $F(B) \in B$ for every set $B$ in $A$.

The interest reader can check out [@mendelson_introduction_2015, pp. 282-284] for a discussion of the Axiom of Choice and its proof of its equivalence with the Trichotomy Law. 

Lets us turn now to the study of finite sets. If $n$ is a positive number let:

$$P_n = \{ k \in \mathbb{P} \mid k \leq n \}$$

For example, $P_1 = \{ 1 \}, P_2 = \{ 1, 2 \}, \ldots P_n = \{ 1, \ldots, n \}$

::: {#def-finite-set}

## Finite set

We say that a set $A$ is finite if and only if:

$$A = \emptyset \lor \exists n (A \approx P_n)$$

:::

The notion in @def-finite-set should be distinguished from the notion of finite sequence. By a finite sequence we mean function $a: P_n \longrightarrow A$ for some positive number $n$. The number $n$ is called the length of the sequence and the values of the function, $a(k)$ where $k \leq n$, are called the terms of the sequence. Also it is traditional to write $a_k$ instead of $a(k)$.

::: {#def-infinite-set}

## Infinite set

We say that a set $A$ is infinite if and only if it is not finite. That is:

$$A \neq \emptyset \land \neg\exists n (A \approx P_n)$$

**Note**: $A \neq \emptyset \land \neg\exists n (A \approx P_n)$ is also equivalent to $A \neq \emptyset \land \forall n (A \not \approx P_n)$.  

:::

::: {#lem-not-equinumerous-with-proper-subsets-pn}

$P_n$ is not equinumerous with any of its proper subsets. That is:

$$\forall A (A \subset P_n \Longrightarrow A \not \approx P_n)$$

:::

::: {.proof}

The result will be prove by strong induction on $n$. 

*Base step* $(n = 1)$: If $P_1 = \{ 1 \}$ then $\emptyset \subset P_1$. Let $F: \emptyset \longrightarrow P_1$ where this function is well defined because $F = \{ (x,y) \mid x \in \emptyset \land y \in P_1 \} = \emptyset$. Also if $x \emptyset y$ and $x \emptyset z$ then $y = z$ is true because $x \emptyset y$ and $x \emptyset z$ is false.

Furthermore by @def-one-one-function $F$ is one-one because $\mathscr{D}(F) = \emptyset$ so $x \in \mathscr{D}(F) \land y \in \mathscr{D}(F) \land x \neq y$ is false and $(x \in \mathscr{D}(F) \land y \in \mathscr{D}(F) \land x \neq y) \Longrightarrow F(x) \neq F(y))$ is true.

However, by @def-onto-function $F$ is not onto because $\mathscr{R}(F) = \emptyset$ so $\exists x(x \in \emptyset \land F(x) = y)$ is false so $\forall y (y \in P_1 \Longrightarrow \exists x(x \in \emptyset \land F(x) = y))$ is false.

Therefore $\emptyset \not \approx P_1$ because we have only that $F: \emptyset \xrightarrow[]{1-1} P_1$ but not $F: \emptyset \xrightarrow[onto]{} P_1$.

*Induction hypothesis* $(n \leq k)$: $\forall A (A \subset P_k \Longrightarrow A \not \approx P_k)$

*Induction step* $(n = k + 1)$: Let use @nte-proof-by-reductio-ad-absurdum. Suppose that $\neg \forall A (A \subset P_{k+1} \Longrightarrow A \not \approx P_{k+1})$, so $\exists A (A \subset P_{k+1} \land A \approx P_{k+1})$. By @thm-equinumerous-equivalence-relation $\exists A (A \subset P_{k+1} \land P_{k+1} \approx A)$. Therefore, it exist some $G$ such that $G: P_{k+1} \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} A$. Then we have 2 cases:

- *Case 1* $G(k+1) = k + 1$: Then ${G \mid}_{P_k}: P_k \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} A - \{ k + 1 \}$ where ${G \mid}_{P_k}$ is the restriction of $G$ to the domain $P_k$ [See @stoll_sets_1974, p. 40]. Therefore $P_k \approx A - \{ k + 1 \}$, so $A - \{ k + 1 \} \approx P_k$. Since $A \subset P_{k+1}$ then $A - \{ k + 1 \} \subset P_k$ where there is a contradiction taking into account the *Induction hypothesis*. So it must be the case that $A \not \approx P_{k+1}$

- *Case 2* $G(k + 1) \neq k + 1$: Then $k + 1 \not \in A$ or $k + 1 \in A$

    - If $k + 1 \not \in A$ then ${G \mid}_{P_k}: P_k \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} A - G(k + 1)$ where ${G \mid}_{P_k}$ is the restriction of $G$ to the domain $P_k$ [See @stoll_sets_1974, p. 40]. Therefore $P_k \approx A - G(k + 1)$, so $A - G(k + 1) \approx P_k$. Because $k + 1 \not \in A$ and $G(k + 1) \in A$ then $A - G(k + 1) \subset P_k$ where there is a contradiction taking into account the *Induction hypothesis*. So it must be the case that $A \not \approx P_{n+1}$  

    - If $k + 1 \in A$ then there is some $i \in P_n$ such that $G(i) = k + 1$ and some $j \in P_n$ such that $G(j) = k + 1$. Therefore we can define a function $F: P_k \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} A - \{k + 1\}$ as:
    
      $$F(x) = \begin{cases}
                G(x) & \text{ if } x \neq i \lor x \neq j \\
                i & \text{ if } x = j
                \end{cases}$$

      Therefore $P_k \approx A - \{ k + 1 \}$, so $A - \{ k + 1 \} \approx P_k$. Since $A \subset P_{k+1}$ then $A - \{ k + 1 \} \subset P_k$ where there is a contradiction taking into account the *Induction hypothesis*. So it must be the case that $A \not \approx P_{k+1}$
:::

::: {#thm-not-equinumerous-with-proper-subsets-finite-set}

If $B$ is a finite set then $B$ is not equinumerous with any of its proper subsets.

:::

::: {.proof}

If $B = \emptyset$ then $B$ has no proper subsets.

If $B \neq \emptyset$ then $B \approx P_n$. Therefore there is some $F: B \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} P_n$. Let an arbitrary $C \subset B$ and $F[C] = \mathscr{R}({F \mid}_{C}) \subset P_n$. So $C \approx F[C]$ because ${F \mid}_{C}: C \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} \mathscr{R}({F \mid}_{C})$ and by @lem-not-equinumerous-with-proper-subsets-pn $F[C] \not \approx P_n$.

Therefore because $C \approx F[C]$ and $F[C] \not \approx P_n$ it must be the case that $C \not \approx P_n$. Furthermore because $B \approx P_n$ then $P_n \approx B$, so it must be the case that $C \not \approx B$.

**Note**: The property pointed out in @thm-not-equinumerous-with-proper-subsets-finite-set is a characteristic of the finite sets.
:::

::: {#cor-not-equinumerous-with-proper-subsets-finite-set}

a. $n \neq k \Longrightarrow P_n \not \approx P_k$

b. If $B$ is finite then either $B = \emptyset$ or there is a unique positive integer $n$ such that $B \approx P_n$ 

:::

::: {.proof}

a. Assume without loss of generality that $n < k$ then $P_n \subset P_k$. By @lem-not-equinumerous-with-proper-subsets-pn $P_n \not \approx P_k$.

b. If $B$ is finite then $B = \emptyset$ or $B \approx P_n$ for some $n$. Assume there is another $m \neq n$ such that $B \approx P_m$. But by @cor-not-equinumerous-with-proper-subsets-finite-set there will be a contradiction so it must be the case that $m = n$. Therefore there is a unique $n$ such that $B \approx P_n$.

:::

If $B \approx P_n$ we say that $B$ has $n$ elements or that $n$ is the number of elements in $B$. Also we assign the following cardinal numbers $\mathscr{K}(\emptyset) = 0$ and $\mathscr{K}(P_n) = n$. Thus if $B$ has $n$ elements $\mathscr{K}(B)=n$.

::: {#thm-finite-set}

a. If $B$ is finite so is $B \cup \{ y \}$.

b. If $B$ is finite and $D \subseteq B$ then $D$ is finite.

c. If $B$ is finite and $D \leq B$ then $D$ is finite.

:::

::: {.proof}

a. If $B$ is finite then $B = \emptyset$ or $B \approx P_n$ for some $n$. Therefore:

    - $\emptyset \cup \{ y \} = \{ y \}$ so $\{ y \} \approx P_1$.
    
    - $F: B \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} P_n$ so $G: B \cup \{ y \} \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} P_{n + 1}$ where
    
      $$G(x) = \begin{cases}
                F(x) & \text{ if } x \neq y \\
                n + 1 & \text{ if } x = y
                \end{cases}$$    

b. First we prove the following partial result $\forall D (D \subseteq P_n \Longrightarrow D \text{ is finite})$ by strong induction on $n$.

   *Base step* $(n = 1)$: If $D \subseteq P_1$ then $D = \emptyset$ so $D$ is finite or $D = \{ 1 \}$ so $D \approx P_1$ so $D$ is also finite.
   
   *Induction hypothesis* $(n \leq k)$: $\forall D (D \subseteq P_k \Longrightarrow D \text{ is finite})$

   *Induction step* $(n = k + 1)$: Let $D \subseteq P_{n + 1}$ and $D^* = D - \{ n + 1 \} \subseteq P_n$. Therefore by the *Induction hypothesis* $D^*$ is finite and $D = D^*$ or $D = D^* \cup \{ n + 1 \}$. By @thm-finite-set $D$ is finite.
   
   Second, if $B$ is finite and $D \subseteq B$ then $B = \emptyset$ or $B \approx P_n$.
   
   - If $B = \emptyset$ then $D = \emptyset$ and $D$ is finite.
   
   - If $B \approx P_n$ then it exists some $F: B \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} P_n$. So, ${F \mid }_{D}: D \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} \mathscr{R}({F \mid }_{D})$ where $\mathscr{R}({F \mid }_{D}) \subseteq P_n$ which means that $D \approx \mathscr{R}({F \mid }_{D})$ and $\mathscr{R}({F \mid }_{D})$ is finite by the above partial result.
   
     Because $\mathscr{R}({F \mid }_{D})$ is finite then $\mathscr{R}({F \mid }_{D}) = \emptyset$ or there is a unique positive integer $m$ such that $\mathscr{R}({F \mid }_{D}) \approx P_m$ by @cor-not-equinumerous-with-proper-subsets-finite-set b. Because $D \approx \mathscr{R}({F \mid }_{D})$ and $\mathscr{R}({F \mid }_{D}) \approx P_m$ then $D \approx P_m$ so $D$ is finite.

c. If $D \leq B$ then $F: D \xrightarrow[]{1-1} B$ where $\mathscr{R}(F) \subseteq B$, so $F: D \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} \mathscr{R}(F)$ and $D \approx \mathscr{R}(F)$. By @thm-finite-set b because $B$ is finite and $\mathscr{R}(F) \subseteq B$ we have that $\mathscr{R}(F)$ is finite.

   Because $\mathscr{R}(F)$ is finite by @cor-not-equinumerous-with-proper-subsets-finite-set b $\mathscr{R}(F) = \emptyset$ or there is a unique positive integer $m$ such that $\mathscr{R}(F) \approx P_m$. Taking into account that $\mathscr{R}(F) = \emptyset$ or $D \approx \mathscr{R}(F)$ and $\mathscr{R}(F) \approx P_m$ then $D = \emptyset$ by @exr-equinumerous-relation 1 or $D \approx P_m$ by @thm-equinumerous-equivalence-relation c. Therefore, $D$ is also finite.  

:::

::: {#exr-finite-infinite-set}

1. If $D$ is infinite and $D \subseteq B$ prove that $B$ is infinite.

2. If $D$ is infinite and $D \leq B$ prove that $B$ is infinite. 

3. Assume $B$ is finite, $D \subset B$, $\mathscr{K}(B) = n$ and $\mathscr{K}(D) = k$. Prove that $k < n$.  

:::

::: {#sol-finite-set}

1. Using @thm-finite-set b we can use its contraposition and @def-infinite-set. That is, $B$ is finite then $B$ is finite or $D \not \subseteq B$. But $D \subseteq B$ so it must be the case that $B$ is finite. 

2. Using @thm-finite-set c we can use its contraposition and @def-infinite-set. That is, $B$ is finite then $D$ is finite or $D \not \leq B$. But $D \leq B$ so it must be the case that $B$ is finite.

3. We have that $n = k$, $n < k$ or $n > k$. 

    - Because $B$ is finite and $D \subset B$ by @thm-not-equinumerous-with-proper-subsets-finite-set it can not be that $n = k$.
    
    - Because $\mathscr{K}(P_n) = n$ and $\mathscr{K}(P_k) = k$ if $n < k$ then $P_n \subset P_k$. Therefore, let $F: P_n \xrightarrow[]{1-1} P_k$ where $F(x) = x$ then $P_n \leq P_k$.
    
      Furthermore, because $B \approx P_n$, $P_n \leq P_k$, and $P_k \approx D$ then $B \leq P_n$, $P_n \leq P_k$, and $P_k \leq D$. By @thm-less-equal-than-and-less-than-relation-sets $B \leq D$. 
    
      Also by @thm-not-equinumerous-with-proper-subsets-finite-set $D \not \approx B$. Additionally, let $F: D \xrightarrow[]{1-1} B$ where $G(x) = x$ then $D \leq B$.
      
      Therefore we have that $D \not \approx B$, $D \leq B$ and $B \leq D$. But then $D \not \approx B$ and by @thm-schroder-bernstein-theorem $D \approx B$ which is a contradiction. So it can not be that $n < k$.
      
    - Because it is not possible that $n = k$ and $n < k$ then it must be the case that $n > k$. 

:::

::: {#thm-positive-integers-equinumerous-proper-subset}

The set $\mathbb{P}$ of positive integers is equinumerous with a proper subset of itself.

:::

::: {.proof}

Let $\mathbb{P} - \{ 1 \} \subset \mathbb{P}$ and $\varphi(n) = n + 1$ where $\varphi: \mathbb{P} \longrightarrow \mathbb{P} - \{ 1 \}$ then:

- If $\varphi(n) = \varphi(m)$ then $n + 1 = m + 1$. So $n = m$ and $\varphi$ is one-one function. 

- Also if $n \in \mathbb{P}$ it always exists $n + 1 \in \mathbb{P} - \{ 1 \}$. So $\varphi$ is an onto function.

Therefore $\varphi: \mathbb{P} \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} \mathbb{P} - \{ 1 \}$, which means that $\mathbb{P} \approx \mathbb{P} - \{ 1 \}$.  

:::

::: {#cor-positive-integers-infinite-set}

The set $\mathbb{P}$ of positive integers is infinite

:::

::: {.proof}

By @thm-positive-integers-equinumerous-proper-subset $\mathbb{P}$ is equinumerous with a proper subset of itself. Therefore by the contrapositive of @thm-not-equinumerous-with-proper-subsets-finite-set $\mathbb{P}$ must be infinite. 

:::

::: {#def-denumerable-set}

## Denumerable set

A set $B$ is said to be denumerable if and only if $B \approx \mathbb{P}$

**Note**: Any set $A$ that is equinumerous with a denumerable set $B$ is denumerable becuase $A \approx B$ and $B \approx \mathbb{P}$ by @thm-equinumerous-equivalence-relation c. implies $A \approx \mathbb{P}$. 

Also if $B$ is denumerable let $B^* = B - \{ x \}$ where $x \in B$. So $B^* \subset B$. Furthermore because $B$ is denumerable it exists $F$ such that $F: B \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} \mathbb{P}$. Lets define ${F \mid}_{B^*}: B^* \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} \mathbb{P} - \{ 1 \}$. Therefore $B^* \approx \mathbb{P} - \{ 1 \}$ but $\mathbb{P} - \{ 1 \} \approx \mathbb{P}$ and $\mathbb{P} \approx B$, which means that $B^* \approx B$. So by @thm-positive-integers-equinumerous-proper-subset, @cor-positive-integers-infinite-set and the contrapositive of @thm-not-equinumerous-with-proper-subsets-finite-set every denumerable set is equinumerous with a proper subset of itself and therefore every denumerable set is infinite[^appendix_d-3].

:::

[^appendix_d-3]: A denumerable set must be distinguished from a **denumerable sequence**. The latter is a function $a: \mathbb{P} \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} A$

::: {#exr-denumerable-sets}

1. Prove that any infinite set $B$ contains a denumerable set. (Hint: This requires the Axiom of Choice, which provides a function $\psi$ such that $\psi(D) \in D$ for all non empty subsets $D$ of $B$. Define, by @thm-iteration-theorem, a function $\theta: \mathbb{P} \longrightarrow B$ such that $\theta(1) = \psi(B)$ and $\theta(n+1) = \psi(B - \theta(n))$. Then $\theta: \mathbb{P} \xrightarrow[]{1-1} B$ and $\mathscr{R}(\theta)$ is a denumerable subset of $B$).

2. Show that any infinite set $B$ is equinumerous with a proper subset of itself. (Hint: By @exr-denumerable-sets 1. let $D$ be an infinite denumerable subset of $B$. Let $\varphi$ be a one-one correspondance between $D$ and a proper subset of $D$. Extend $\varphi$ to a function $\varphi^*$ defined on $B$ by letting $\varphi^*(u) = u$ for any $u \in B - D$. The $\varphi^*$ is a one-one correspondence between $B$ and a proper subset of itself.)

:::

::: {#sol-denumerable-sets}

1. There is a problem with the hint because $B - \theta(n)$ is not well define. But the general idea of the hint is correct. 

   By the axiom of choice let $S = \{D \subseteq B \mid D \neq \emptyset \}$. So there exists a function $\psi$ such that $\psi: S \longrightarrow \bigcup S$ where $\psi(D) \in D$ and $\bigcup S \subseteq B$.

   By @thm-iteration-theorem define a function $\theta: \mathbb{P} \longrightarrow B$ such that:
  
     a. $\theta(1) = \psi(B)$ where $\psi(B) \in B$
     b. $\theta(n + 1) = g(\theta(n)) = \psi(B - \{\theta(i) \mid i \in \mathbb{P} \land 1 \leq i \leq n \})$
  
   Then $\theta: \mathbb{P} \longrightarrow B$. 
   Let's prove $\theta$ is one-one. Assume $\theta(n) = \theta(m)$ and $n \neq m$. Without loss of generality assume $n < m$. Therefore $\theta(m) = \psi(B - \{\theta(i) \mid i \in \mathbb{P} \land 1 \leq i \leq m-1 \})$ so $\theta(m) \not \in \{\theta(i) \mid i \in \mathbb{P} \land 1 \leq i \leq m-1 \}$. However $n \leq m-1$ so $\theta(n) \in \{\theta(i) \mid i \in \mathbb{P} \land 1 \leq i \leq m-1 \}$. But $\theta(n) = \theta(m)$ so there is a contradiction because we also have that $\theta(m) \in \{\theta(i) \mid i \in \mathbb{P} \land 1 \leq i \leq m-1 \}$. Therefore is must be the case that $\theta(n) = \theta(m) \Longrightarrow n = m)$ or that $\theta$ is one-one. That is, $\theta: \mathbb{P} \xrightarrow[]{1-1} B$.

   Using the above result $\theta: \mathbb{P} \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} \mathscr{R}(\theta)$ where $\mathscr{R}(\theta) \subseteq B$ so $\mathscr{R}(\theta)$ is a denumerable set.

2. If $B$ is infinite then by @exr-denumerable-sets 1 there is denumerable subset $D$ such that $D \subseteq B$.

   In case $D = B$ the $D \approx B$ so $B$ is denumerable and by @def-denumerable-set there is some $C \subset B$ such that $C \approx B$.
   
   In case $D \subset B$ then by @def-denumerable-set there is some $C$ such that $C \subset D$ and some function $\varphi$ such that $\varphi: C \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} D$. Now let $\varphi^*$ such that:
   
   $$\varphi^*(u) = \begin{cases}
                    \varphi(u) & \text{if } u \in C \\
                    u          & \text{if } u \in B - D
                    \end{cases}$$
   
   First, $\varphi^*$ is one-one because if $\varphi^*(u) = \varphi^*(v)$ then $\varphi(u) = \varphi(v)$ but $\varphi$ is one-one so $u = v$ or $u = v$. Therefore in any case $u = v$.
   
   Second, $\varphi^*$ is onto because if $u \in B$ then $u \in D$ or $u \in B - D$. So if $u \in D$ because $\varphi$ is onto there exist some $c \in C$ such that $\varphi(c) = u$. Also if $u \in B - D$ then $\varphi^*(u) = u$.
   
   Therefore we have that $\varphi^*(u): C \cup (B - D) \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} B$ where $C \cup (B - D) \subset B$.
  
:::

::: {#thm-finite-set-2}

Assume that $A$ and $B$ are finite. Then

a. $A \cap B$ is finite
b. $A \cup B$ is finite
c. $A \times B$ is finite
d. $\mathscr{P}(A)$ is finite

:::

::: {.proof}

a. Because $A \cap B \subseteq A$ and $A$ is finite then by @thm-finite-set b $A \cap B$ is finite.

b. Let $A$ be finite. Then $B = \emptyset$ or $B \approx P_n$.

   If $B = \emptyset$ then $A \cap B = \emptyset$ so $A \cap B$ is finite.
   
   If $B \approx P_n$ then we use @def-peano-system iii.
   
     - *Base step* $(n = 1)$: Then $B = \{ y \}$ for some $y$. Therefore $A \cup B = A \cup \{ y \}$. By @thm-finite-set a $A \cup B$ is finite.
     
     - *Induction hypothesis* $(n \leq k)$: Assume that $B \approx P_k$ then if $A \cup B$ is finite.
     
     - *Induction step* $(n = k + 1)$: Let $B \approx P_{k+1}$. Therefore there is some $\theta: B \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} P_{k+1}$. By @thm-inverse-function-as-a-function $\theta^{-1}: P_{k+1} \xrightarrow[onto]{1-1} B$. Therefore we can define $B^* = B - \{ \theta^{-1}(k+1)\}$ so $B^* \approx P_k$ and $A \cup B^*$ is finite by the induction hypothesis. By @thm-finite-set a because $A \cup B = (A \cup B^*) \cup \{ \theta^{-1}(k+1)\}$ then $A \cup B$ is finite. 

:::
